title: Point 1
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria or to score the response.

To earn this point, responses must demonstrate the following:

  • Accesses all elements of apples

Canonical Solution: 

public int numberOfPies(double poundsPerPie)
{
   double weight = 0;
 
   for (int r = 0; r < apples.length; r++)
   {
      for (int c = 0; c < apples[0].length; c++)
      {
         boolean bad = apples[r][c].isRotten();
 
         if (r > 0 && apples[r - 1][c].isRotten())
         {
            bad = true;
         }
         if (r < apples.length - 1 && 
             apples[r + 1][c].isRotten())
         {
            bad = true;
         }
         if (c > 0 && apples[r][c - 1].isRotten())
         {
            bad = true;
         }
         if (c < apples[0].length - 1 && 
             apples[r][c + 1].isRotten())
         {
            bad = true;
         }
 
         if (!bad)
         {
            weight += apples[r][c].getWeight();
         }
      }
   }
   return (int)(weight / poundsPerPie);
}
descriptions:
The response does not earn the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • access elements of apples out of bounds as part of adjacency checking, as long as loop bounds support traversing every element

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • fail to access elements of apples correctly

The response earns the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • access elements of apples out of bounds as part of adjacency checking, as long as loop bounds support traversing every element

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • fail to access elements of apples correctly

title: Point 2
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria or to score the response.

To earn this point, responses must demonstrate the following:

  • Calls isRotten and getWeight on an Apple object

Canonical Solution:

The response does not earn the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • fail to access elements of apples correctly

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • call isRotten or getWeight incorrectly

The response earns the point.

  • fail to access elements of apples correctly

Responses will not earn the point if they

title: Point 3
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria or to score the response.

To earn this point, responses must demonstrate the following:

Canonical Solution:

title: Point 5
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria or to score the response.

To earn this point, responses must demonstrate the following:

  • Identifies non-usable apples (algorithm)

Canonical Solution:

public int numberOfPies(double poundsPerPie)
{
   double weight = 0;
 
   for (int r = 0; r < apples.length; r++)
   {
      for (int c = 0; c < apples[0].length; c++)
      {
         boolean bad = apples[r][c].isRotten();
 
         if (r > 0 && apples[r - 1][c].isRotten())
         {
            bad = true;
         }
         if (r < apples.length - 1 && 
             apples[r + 1][c].isRotten())
         {
            bad = true;
         }
         if (c > 0 && apples[r][c - 1].isRotten())
         {
            bad = true;
         }
         if (c < apples[0].length - 1 && 
             apples[r][c + 1].isRotten())
         {
            bad = true;
         }
 
         if (!bad)
         {
            weight += apples[r][c].getWeight();
         }
      }
   }
   return (int)(weight / poundsPerPie);
}
descriptions:
The response does not earn the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • call isRotten incorrectly

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • fail to call isRotten
  • fail to check current location for rot
  • fail to check all adjacent locations
  • combine the check for rotten apples with incorrect logic
  • fail to guard access of adjacent elements to prevent bounds error

The response earns the point.

title: Point 6
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria or to score the response.

To earn this point, responses must demonstrate the following:

  • Returns correct integer number of pies (algorithm)

Canonical Solution: 

public int numberOfPies(double poundsPerPie)
{
   double weight = 0;
 
   for (int r = 0; r < apples.length; r++)
   {
      for (int c = 0; c < apples[0].length; c++)
      {
         boolean bad = apples[r][c].isRotten();
 
         if (r > 0 && apples[r - 1][c].isRotten())
         {
            bad = true;
         }

             apples[r + 1][c].isRotten())

            bad = true;

            bad = true;
         }
 
         if (!bad)

            weight += apples[r][c].getWeight();

   }
   return (int)(weight / poundsPerPie);
}
